verse.roman:
aho bhaginy aho bhāma
mayā vāṁ bata pāpmanā
puruṣāda ivāpatyaṁ
bahavo hiṁsitāḥ sutāḥ

synonyms: aho—alas; bhagini—my dear sister; aho—alas; bhāma—my dear brother-in-law; mayā—by me; vām—of you; bata—indeed; pāpmanā—because of sinful activities; puruṣa-adaḥ—a Rākṣasa, man-eater; iva—like; apatyam—child; bahavaḥ—many; hiṁsitāḥ—have been killed; sutāḥ—sons.
translation: Alas, my sister! Alas, my brother-in-law! I am indeed so sinful that exactly like a man-eater [Rākṣasa] who eats his own child, I have killed so many sons born of you.

purport.text: Rākṣasas are understood to be accustomed to eating their own sons, as snakes and many other animals sometimes do. At the present moment in Kali-yuga, Rākṣasa fathers and mothers are killing their own children in the womb, and some are even eating the fetus with great relish. Thus the so-called civilization is gradually advancing by producing Rākṣasas.
